title: Use glutin 0.22.0-alpha6
body: 0.22.0-alpha6 locks winit to a compatible version, it fails to compile otherwise because it tries to use winit 0.20.0 instead of 0.20.0-alpha4 (see https://github.com/rust-windowing/glutin/commit/5947a22bbd62fe3b39601d6100563aaab352a315#diff-1b6d60f3f005be6e1e05f2803da7ccc6)

title: Report which shader stage failed to compile
body:
When compiling a program composed of multiple shader stages, glium would not previously report which shader stage failed to compile. The error message from the driver would include line numbers, but the user had to guess which file actually failed to compile.

This commit makes the error data type include which shader stage actually failed to compile.

title: Fix wrong element count for some attribute types
body:
Fix wrong element count for attributes I2I10I10I10Reversed, U2U10U10U10Reversed, I10I10I10I2, U10U10U10U2 and F10F11F11UnsignedIntReversed. 

Without this fix, the above mentioned attributes don't work. The attributes are useful for packing RGB-colors into a 32 bit compressed representation, for example, which saves memory bandwidth and increases performance.

See issue #1811

title: Make window used for screenshot visible
body:
For some reason, this is required for
the screenshot example to work,
otherwise it would just create an empty
image.

Fixes #1800

title: Avoid infinite recursion in conversion functions
body:
This fixes a regression introduced by
1fe97f8e1b541b1c5e21bc1495fbb786d747ef20.
It avoids calling into() which previously
caused an infinite recursion ending in a
segfault.

Fixes #1806

title: Remove the check of naming when buiding TransformFeedbackSession.
body:
When creating `TransformFeedbackSession`, `glium` would check the consistent of naming, offset and type between the input attributes of output buffer and output attributes of input buffer(both are attributes in vertex buffer).
The offset and type checking is OK. But the check of naming make TransformFeedback difficult to use.

Because when implementing particles system, we usually use two transformfeedback buffer(`buffer1` and `buffer2`) with the same vertex type. In first render pass, `buffer1` is for input and `buffer2` is for output. Then in the second render pass, we swap the position of them(e.g. `buffer1` is for output, `buffer2` is for input).
The problem is that `glium` will stop me due to a fact that the naming of input and output attributes are different. But they must be different, or we can't distinguish what is input attributes and output attributes. This causes a self-contradiction condition.

So we just need to remove the check for naming in TransformFeedback buffer and then everything works fine.

title: Fix benchmarks
body:
Benchmarks needed a tiny bit of love. They're running again.

Tested via `cargo bench --all-features`.

- Adds a dev dependency on libc (required by benchmarks)
- Fixes some imports
- Fixes a template error on Context
- Some small formatting fixes

The `from_raw_rgb`, and `from_raw_rgba` methods on `RawImage1d` provide easy
construction from a vector of pixels.

Includes @Mufferaw's fix for the camera position, as well as using saturated sub to avoid a panic when the mouse is at the bottom of the screen.

(I opened a new PR, since I had deleted my fork since opening it, so I couldn't update #1542.)

body: Fix issue #1538. I couldn't replicate the subtract with overflow component of the issue on ubuntu though.

title: Lokathor removes mem::uninitialized
body:
Closes https://github.com/glium/glium/issues/1753

* https://github.com/glium/glium/commit/a5529204ae8925aa2ad6912b42fe64d34b838b78 isn't a complete fix, this is still a dangerous thing to do but people are _not likely_ to actually make it go wrong. There is a soundness hole here, people are just unlikely to walk into it.
* https://github.com/glium/glium/commit/4609e7caf8c523ebe14e038b9ab523e53db9de04 is still dangerous but I've at least documented a bit about what you're not supposed to do, and I don't think people are making many vertex structs that can't be zeroed.
* Everything else was just ints, floats, or arrays of ints. Absolutely trivial, we don't even need `MaybeUninit`, we just use a literal `0`.

Updated the dependencies, and changed the parts of the code where the EventLoop struct appears. This bumps the glium version to 0.25.1-alpha1.
The examples have not been updated or tested yet.

title: Don't call `glDisable` when not needed
body:
- Added an `enabled_clip_planes` bitmask to `GlState`
- Changed `sync_clip_planes_bitmask` to only change state if `clip_planes_bitmask` is divergent from `enabled_clip_planes`
- Changed `sync_primitive_restart_index` to only change state if `enabled` diverges from `enabled_primitive_fixed_restart`

title: Update dependencies, unbreak examples
body: This PR updates the glutin dependency to 0.20, as well as some other dependencies, so that cargo-outdated doesn't complain any more. Also, it issues a new release and unbreaks the shadow mapping example which previously failed to compile.

title: Update glutin dependency to 0.19.
body:
Based on @Lycowolf's #1711 branch, but updates the version to 0.19 rather than 0.18. This includes accounting for the recent consolidation of the `glutin::HeadlessContext` type into the `glutin::Context` type. I've updated the glium CHANGELOG with a link to the glutin 0.19 CHANGELOG entry for further details.

Closes #1711.
Closes #1704.

cc @Lycowolf, @daboross

title: Add BorderClamp to Sampler
body: I have added GL_CLAMP_TO_BORDER as BorderClamp. GL_CLAMP_TO_BORDER evaluates s coordinates in a similar manner to GL_CLAMP_TO_EDGE,  however is useful in some other cases.

title: Depth Comparison and Shadow Mapping
body: Adds an option for a depth texture comparison function to the sampler and creates an example demonstrating shadow mapping.

title: report depth and stencil bit counts for DepthStencil attachments
body: Resolves #253

title: Add repr(C) for Data struct in gpgpu-example
body: This struct should be repr(C), since nothing is guaranteed about the struct layout in rust without this directive. And we *are* actually relying on the struct layout ending up identically to the OpenGL std140-layout (which, with our explicit padding, it will if be guaranteed to if we specify repr(C)).
